an4.173:1.1: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.
an4.173:1.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Mahākoṭṭhita sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:
an4.173:2.1: “Reverend, when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, does something else still exist?”
an4.173:6.1: “Does something else both still exist and no longer exist?”
an4.173:8.1: “Does something else neither still exist nor no longer exist?”
an4.173:10.1: “Reverend, when asked whether—when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over—something else still exists, you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.2: When asked whether something else no longer exists,
an4.173:10.3: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.4: When asked whether something else both still exists and no longer exists,
an4.173:10.5: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.6: When asked whether something else neither still exists nor no longer exists,
an4.173:10.7: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.8: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
an4.173:11.1: “If you say that, ‘When the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, something else still exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.2: If you say that ‘something else no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.3: If you say that ‘something else both still exists and no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.4: If you say that ‘something else neither still exists nor no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.5: The scope of proliferation extends as far as the scope of the six fields of contact.
an4.173:11.6: The scope of the six fields of contact extends as far as the scope of proliferation.
an4.173:11.7: When the six fields of contact fade away and cease with nothing left over, proliferation stops and is stilled.”
